title: Documentation: inline code with links split into multiple blocks

labels.name: C-enhancement

body: **EDIT(camelid): ⚠️ Please do not open a PR for this! It is still under discussion.** ----- Right now in the standard library documentation, when a piece of inline code has part of it linked, the code is split into multiple `` blocks, which renders poorly. For example the [`Arc` thread safety section](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#thread-safety) contains ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18604588/114037935-b6340e00-9881-11eb-9739-0b5b62b03158.png) Here, between `Arc<` and `RefCell`, and between `` and `>`, there is extra spacing. This is because the doc comment contains ```rust /// `Arc<`[`RefCell`]`>` ``` which is rendered using three `` blocks as ```html Arc<RefCell<T>> ``` I think better would be ```rust /// Arc<[RefCell<T>][RefCell]> ``` which presumably is rendered in one block as ```html Arc<RefCell<T>> ``` (I'm not sure if the link to `RefCell` gets a `title` attribute as well). The downside is that now the doc comment markdown is a bit hairy with explicit ``, `<` and `>` spread throughout. Is this substitution considered an improvement? If so I can grep through the code, make some substitutions, and open a PR. An alternative solution would be to change rustdoc itself to combine consecutive code blocks, some of which could be wrapped inside ``/``, into a single block, though I do not have the know-how to open such a PR. I don't even know if there is some downside to this that I am missing, where `` blocks are meant to be separate, maybe for some markdown compliance or something.
